header.title: CC3S - Cervical Cancer Screening Scenario Simulator

footer.usDepartmentOfHealthAndHumanServices: U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

home.introdution: Explore clinical and epidemiological outcomes for target populations with our screening impact assessment tool.
home.whatIsCC3SDes: Cervical Cancer Screening Scenario Simulator (CC3S) is a scenario tool developed by the National Cancer Institute Center for Global Health (NCI/CGH) to assist health officials and/or providers planning and understanding their national cervical cancer screening program at different levels of the health system. You can use this tool to visualize how effective a program might be and what resources would be required depending on variable options of screening coverage, frequency, tests utilized, test accuracy and follow-up in your local context. This tool is meant to facilitate conversations amongst partners.
home.insightDes: CC3S is an easy-to-use tool created to inform and facilitate decision-making to create feasible cervical cancer screening programs. Please note that the figures and numbers are simplified and not meant to precisely reflect real-world planning. This tool is meant to be used for comparing assumptions and strategies for cervical cancer screening programs. CC3S considers the resource and impact of only one screening round.
home.jusdgementFreeDes: There is no right or wrong answer. Feel free to test your assumptions and consider screening and triage options that could help design the most appropriate and feasible screening strategy for your unique setting.
home.engageDes: It is natural to encounter many questions about your results. We encourage you to use the findings as discussion material with your team(s) and key local partners.
home.des0: Are you ready to discover CC3S? Navigate to the
home.des0Continued: tab to start planning your cervical cancer prevention strategy!
home.des1: If you have any questions or technical issues, please select
home.emphasize: This tool is best used with a trained facilitator to guide you through the decision-making process, but you are welcome to use it on your own. Please
home.desLink0: For more information, navigate to the
home.desLink1: tab for key definitions, descriptions, and evidence for scenario parameters in CC3S.

general.ccpTitle: CC3S - Cervical Cancer Screening Scenario Simulator
general.specificityHelpText: Go to about page section 'Screening Strategy Characteristics' for more information

runScenario.title: Run Scenario
runScenario.epidemiologicalTitle: Explore epidemiological outcomes for target populations with our screening impact assessment tool.
runScenario.numPeople: Number of people in target population for cervical screening
runScenario.numPeopleInfo: Enter targeted number of people in the population eligible for cervical screening - Only numbers allowed as input, no commas or periods.
runScenario.prevelance: Prevalence of CIN2/3 in population for cervical screening
runScenario.prevelanceInfo: Enter number of women with CIN2/3 per 100 people in the population eligible for cervical screening
runScenario.numberWomenWithCin: Enter number of women with CIN2/3 per 100 people in the population eligible for cervical screening
runScenario.strategyChoosen: Please choose strategies to include in your scenario
runScenario.pleaseChooseStrategies: Please choose strategies to include in your scenario by checking the strategy checkbox.
runScenario.participationWarning: Please enter the observed or anticipated participation in the cervical cancer screening program in your setting
runScenario.intervalofCervicalInYears: Interval of cervical screening in years
runScenario.XintervalInformation: If people have one screening in a lifetime, enter 20 years. For two cervical screenings in a lifetime, enter 10 years.
runScenario.intervalInformation: Default value is once in a lifetime and equal to the number of years a person can be in a screening program, calculated by the age range of participants in the target population. For two screens in a lifetime, enter one-half of the default value. Many programs screen every 5 years.
runScenario.percentScreeningPositiveWithTriage: Percent of screen positives with triage test
runScenario.percentTriagePositiveWithDiagnostic: Percent of triage positives with diagnostic test
runScenario.percentTriagePositiveWithColposcopy: Percent of triage positives with colposcopy test
runScenario.percentDiagnosticPositiveTreated: Percent of diagnostic test positives treated
runScenario.screeningAndTreatmentWarning: Please select the screening, triage and diagnostic tests and treatment modality you will use and enter an estimate of their performance characteristics.
runScenario.screeningTestSenvitivity: Screening test sensitivity for CIN2/3
runScenario.screeningTestSpecificity: Screening test specificity for CIN2/3
runScenario.triageTestSensitivity: Triage test sensitivity for CIN2/3
runScenario.triageTestSpecificity: Triage test specificity for CIN2/3
runScenario.triageOrDiagnosticTestSensitivity: Triage or diagnostic test sensitivity for CIN2/3
runScenario.triageOrDiagnosticTestSpecificity: Triage or diagnostic test specificity for CIN2/3
runScenario.diagnosticTestSensitivity: Diagnostic test sensitivity for CIN2/3
runScenario.diagnosticTestSpecificity: Diagnostic test specificity for CIN2/3
runScenario.colposcopyTestSensitivity: Colposcopy test sensitivity for CIN2/3
runScenario.colposcopyTestSpecificity: Colposcopy test specificity for CIN2/3
runScenario.screenTreatHelpText: Percent of those indicated for treatment based on positive result (screening, triage, or colposcopy) that actually receive treatment
runScenario.ScreenDiagnosticTestTreat: Percent of screening or triage/diagnostic test positives treated
runScenario.ScreenTriageDiagnosticTestTreat: Percent of screen positives with triage/diagnostic test
runScenario.percentofScreenPositivesWithDiagnostic: Percent of screen positives with diagnostic test
runScenario.percentofScreenPositivesWithColposcopy: Percent of screen positives with colposcopy test
runScenario.pleaseRefer: Please refer to the About tab for more information about the below parameters before entering a scenario.
runScenario.proportionOfPositives: Proportion of HPV positives including HPV 16/18.
runScenario.proportionOfPositivesInfo: Proportion of those who test HPV+ that also test positive for either HPV16 or HPV18.
runScenario.HPVHelpText: Enter number of women with HPV per 100 people in the population eligible for cervical screening.
runScenario.agesInitEndScreening: Ages initiating and ending cervical screening
runScenario.agesInitEndScreeningInfo: Enter the age range of people included in your screening program.

results.interventionsRequired: Other interventions required in one year
results.screeningBarChartTitle0: Screening interventions required in one year
results.populationWithPrecancer: Population with precancer in one year
results.populationWithoutPrecancer: Population without precancer in one year
results.populationTargetedWithCoverageTitle: Population targeted for screening with 100% coverage
results.populationTargetedWithoutPrecancer: Population targeted for screening without Precancer
results.populationTargetedWithPrecancer: Population targeted for screening with Precancer
results.annualImpactOnCervicalPrecancerTitle: Annual Impact on Cervical Precancer and Impact on the Population Targeted for Screening
results.impactOnCervicalPrecancerTitle: Program Impact on Cervical Precancer and Impact on the Population Targeted for Screening
results.monthlyImpactOnCervicalPrecancerTitle: Average Monthly Impact on Cervical Precancer and Impact on the Population Targeted for Screening
results.percentPolulationTargetedOverTreated: Percent of population targeted for screening without precancer and possibly over-treated
results.totalPrecancersMissed: Total precancers missed (% of all precancers)
results.sourcesMissedPrecancers: Sources of missed precancers (% missed precancers)
results.resultGraphDefinition: These results reflect the anticipated resources, people screened, and estimated preventive impact each year given the indicated program screening interval. Note that the preventive impact reflects one single round of screening and not the accumulated impact of repeat screening over a lifetime.
results.resultGraphDefinition3: Percent of individuals screened per year who are assumed to have precancer*
results.resultGraphDefinition4: Percent of individuals screened per year who are assumed to not have precancer*
results.resultGraphDefinition5: *based on input of precancer prevalence in simulator
results.screeningColposcopyHelpText: Screening programs without colposcopy assume that 4% of women treated will not be eligible for immediate ablation and will require colposcopy.
results.lengthProgramHelpText: The length of a “program” is determined by the selected interval of cervical screening in years.

compareScenarios.uploadScenariosInfo: Upload up to {{limit}} scenarios for comparison. Files must be of the “.scenario” file format. Click the title of the scenario to rename it.

about.title: Description and sources for scenario parameters
about.prevalenceJustification: Population-based prevalence studies suggest 1-3% prevalence, depending upon previous screening history and immunocompetency challenges in the population.
about.prevalenceSources0: Zhao FH, et al. Prevalence of human papillomavirus and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia in China: a pooled analysis of 17 population-based studies. Int J Cancer. 2012 Dec 15;131(12):2929-38.
about.prevalenceSources1: Ting J, et al.  A global review of age-specific and overall prevalence of cervical lesions. Int J Gynecol Cancer. 2010 Oct;20(7):1244-9. doi: 10.1111/igc.0b013e3181f16c5f. PMID: 21495248.
about.prevalenceSources2: Vesco KK et al. Screening for Cervical Cancer: A Systematic Evidence Review for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force [Internet]. Rockville (MD): Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (US); 2011 May. Report No.: 11-05156-EF-1. PMID: 22132428.
about.prevalenceSources3: Web Annex A. Syntheses of evidence. In: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2021. Licence: CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO.
about.prevalenceSources4: Denny L, et al.  Screen-and-treat approaches for cervical cancer prevention in low-resource settings: a randomized controlled trial. JAMA. 2005 Nov 2;294(17):2173-81.
about.prevalenceSources5: Herrero R, et al. Epidemiologic profile of type-specific human papillomavirus infection and cervical neoplasia in Guanacaste, Costa Rica. J Infect Dis. 2005 Jun 1;191(11):1796-807.
about.prevalenceSources6: Sankaranarayanan R, et al. HPV screening for cervical cancer in rural India. N Engl J Med. 2009 Apr 2;360(14):1385-94.
about.prevalenceSources7: Kulasingam SL, et al. Evaluation of human papillomavirus testing in primary screening for cervical abnormalities: comparison of sensitivity, specificity, and frequency of referral. JAMA. 2002 Oct 9;288(14):1749-57.
about.prevalenceSources8: Wright TC Jr, et al. The ATHENA human papillomavirus study: design, methods, and baseline results. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2012 Jan;206(1):46.e1-46.e11.
about.intervalofCervicalInYearsJustification0: Cervical cancer screening guidelines recommend screening no more frequently than every 3 years. Typically, screening intervals range from every 3 or 5 years to every 10 years, depending upon test sensitivity and feasibility to implement screening and follow-up within the health system while maintaining adequate coverage. When considering a once-in-a-lifetime screening approach, enter the value “40”, when considering a twice-in-a-lifetime approach, enter the value “20.”
about.intervalofCervicalInYearsJustification1: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2021. Licence: CC BY-NC-SA 3.0 IGO.
about.intervalofCervicalInYearsJustification2: Fontham ETH, et al. Cervical cancer screening for individuals at average risk: 2020 guideline update from the American Cancer Society. CA Cancer J Clin. 2020;70(5):321-346. doi:10.3322/caac.21628
about.intervalofCervicalInYearsJustification3: Curry SJ, et al. Screening for cervical cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation Statement. JAMA. 2018 Aug 21;320(7):674-686.
about.percentScreeningCoverageJustification: This metric refers to the percent of the population that you aim to reach over the course of their lifetime. Screening coverage varies widely by country, geographic region, resource setting, and population.
about.percentScreeningCoverageSource: Bruni L, et al. Cervical cancer screening programmes and age-specific coverage estimates for 202 countries and territories worldwide: a review and synthetic analysis. Lancet Glob Health. 2022 Aug;10(8):e1115-e1127.
about.percentScreeningPositiveTriageDiagnostic: This metric refers to the percent of those with an abnormal screening result that will receive the subsequent triage or diagnostic test. Follow-up rates vary widely between 25-99%, depending on resources and contexts.

Bruni L, Serrano B, Roura E, Alemany L, Cowan M, Herrero R, Poljak M, Murillo R, Broutet N, Riley LM, de Sanjose S. Cervical cancer screening programmes and age-specific coverage estimates for 202 countries and territories worldwide: a review and synthetic analysis. Lancet Glob Health. 2022 Aug;10(8):e1115-e1127. doi: 10.1016/S2214-109X(22)00241-8. PMID: 35839811; PMCID: PMC9296658.
about.percentTriageDiagnosticTestPositivesJust: This metric refers to the percent of those with an abnormal triage or diagnostic test that will receive treatment. Follow-up rates vary widely between 25-99%, depending on resources and contexts. Screen-and-treat programs tend to have better follow-up with treatment due to fewer steps in management.
about.percentScreeningPositivesTriageJustifica: This metric refers to the percent of those with an abnormal result that will receive the triage/diagnostic test. Follow-up rates vary widely between 25-99%, depending on resources and contexts.
about.percentScreeningPositivesDiagnosisJustif: This metric refers to the percent of those with an abnormal result that will receive the triage/diagnostic test. Follow-up rates vary widely between 25-99%, depending on resources and contexts.
about.percentDiagnosticPositivesTreatedJustifi: This metric refers to the percent of those with an abnormal result that will receive treatment. Follow-up rates vary widely between 25-99%, depending on resources and contexts.
about.percentTriageDiagnosticTestPositivesSour: Murillo, R., et al., Cervical cancer screening programs in Latin America and the Caribbean. Vaccine, 2008. 26 Suppl 11: p. L37-48.
Sankaranarayanan R, et al. HPV screening for cervical cancer in rural India. N Engl J Med. 2009 Apr 2;360(14):1385-94.

Campos NG, Maza M, Alfaro K, Gage JC, Castle PE, Felix JC, Cremer ML, Kim JJ. The comparative and cost-effectiveness of HPV-based cervical cancer screening algorithms in El Salvador. Int J Cancer. 2015 Aug 15;137(4):893-902. doi: 10.1002/ijc.29438. Epub 2015 Feb 3. PMID: 25639903.
about.papTestJustification: Pap test performance varies widely across settings. Sensitivity can range from 25-75%, with most estimates 50-70%
about.papTestSource0: Arbyn M, et al. Pooled analysis of the accuracy of five cervical cancer screening tests assessed in eleven studies in Africa and India. Int J Cancer 2008; 123: 153-160.
about.papTestSource1: Cuzick J, et al. Overview of the European and North American studies on HPV testing in primary cervical cancer screening. IJC.2006;119:1095–1101.
about.papTestSource2: Mayrand HM, et al. Human papillomavirus DNA versus papanicolaou screening tests for cervical cancer. NEJM 2007;357:1579-1588.
about.papTestSource3: Almonte et al. Cervical screening by visual inspection, HPV testing, liquid-based and conventional cytology in Amazonian Peru. IJC 121, 706-802, 2007.
about.papTestSource4: Nanda K et al. Ann Intern Med 2000
about.papTestSource5: Web Annex A. Syntheses of evidence. In: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition. Geneva: World Health Organization
about.viaJustification: Estimates vary wide and depend on training and continued quality control. Global average about 65% sensitivity and 87% specificity. Estimates of test performance following a positive HPV test are similarly wide.
about.viaTestSource1: Table 4.32. Syntheses of evidence. In: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention, second edition. Geneva: World Health Organization
about.hpvJustification: Estimates of HPV test performance in screening programs are less variable. Also, the test specificity can vary depending on the prevalence of HPV in the population.
about.hpvSource1: Cuzick J, et al. Overview of the European and North American studies on HPV testing in primary cervical cancer screening. IJC.2006;119:1095–1101.
about.impressionOfColposcopyJustification: Accuracy of colposcopic impression varies widely with significant bias. Most estimates of sensitivity are 50-80% while estimates of specificity are 70-95%.
about.impressionOfColposcopySource: Brown BH, Tidy JA. The diagnostic accuracy of colposcopy - A review of research methodology and impact on the outcomes of quality assurance. Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol. 2019 Sep;240:182-186. doi: 10.1016/j.ejogrb.2019.07.003. Epub 2019 Jul 3. PMID: 31302386.
about.sensitivity: The percent of the population with precancer/cancer that have a positive test result.
about.specificity: The percent of the population without precancer/cancer that have a negative test result.
about.aboutWhoTile: WHO Cervical Cancer Elimination Initiative Guidance
about.aboutDes0: WHO Strategy to Accelerate the Elimination of Cervical Cancer as a Global Public Health Problem
about.aboutDes1: The goal of the WHO Cervical Cancer Elimination Initiative is for all countries to reach and maintain an incidence rate of below 4 per 100 000 women. Achieving that goal rests on three key pillars and their corresponding targets:
about.aboutDes2: vaccination: 90% of girls fully vaccinated with the HPV vaccine by the age of 15;
about.aboutDes3: screening: 70% of women screened using a high-performance test by the age of 35, and again by the age of 45;
about.aboutDes4: treatment: 90% of women with pre-cancer treated and 90% of women with invasive cancer managed.
about.aboutDes5: Each country will reach the elimination goals at their own pace according to competing priorities, available resources, and planning.
about.overTreatedDef: In a cervical cancer screening program, overtreatment occurs to some extent because a proportion of the people treated have precancer* not destined to progress or some individuals might be treated for a false-positive diagnosis of cervical precancer. Overtreatment can result in side effects and complications, including psychological harms and resource implications. This tool uses the "overtreatment" in a simplified sense and recognizes that the importance and implications of overtreatment may vary by context.
about.overTreatmentStar: *or proportion of persons with HPV infection treated in a screen-and-treat program
about.prevalenceSources9: de Sanjosé S, Diaz M, Castellsagué X, Clifford G, Bruni L, Muñoz N, Bosch FX. Worldwide prevalence and genotype distribution of cervical human papillomavirus DNA in women with normal cytology: a meta-analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2007 Jul;7(7):453-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(07)70158-5. PMID: 17597569.
about.prevalenceSources10: Guan P, Howell-Jones R, Li N, Bruni L, de Sanjosé S, Franceschi S, Clifford GM. Human papillomavirus types in 115,789 HPV-positive women: a meta-analysis from cervical infection to cancer. Int J Cancer. 2012 Nov 15;131(10):2349-59. doi: 10.1002/ijc.27485. Epub 2012 Mar 20. PMID: 22323075.
about.prevalenceSourcesJustification: The prevalence of HPV is highly variable by age, immune status and geography. For women age 30-49, the prevalence is generally around 11-12%. For women under age 25, HPV prevalence is typically much higher, and infections usually resolve within one year. Given geographic variations, we encourage users who do not know the HPV prevalence in their setting to use prevalence estimates based upon observed results among women of similar age in local screening programs or neighboring countries. This tool is not meant for HIV-endemic populations due to variations in HPV epidemiology.
about.fixedAt100HPV1618: Fixed at 100-(HPV prevalence x percent of HPV+ that are HPV 16/18+/)
about.proportionOfPositiveIncludingHPV1618: Proportion of HPV positives including HPV 16/18
about.proportionOfPositiveIncludingHPV1618_Jus: In the general population, the percent of those testing HPV positive with HPV16/18 varies slightly geographically. It is recommended to use preliminary or established data from the screening program or a neighbor settings.
about.proportionOfPositiveIncludingHPV1618_Sou: Guan P, Howell-Jones R, Li N, Bruni L, de Sanjosé S, Franceschi S, Clifford GM. Human papillomavirus types in 115,789 HPV-positive women: a meta-analysis from cervical infection to cancer. Int J Cancer. 2012 Nov 15;131(10):2349-59. doi: 10.1002/ijc.27485. Epub 2012 Mar 20. PMID: 22323075.

Forman D, de Martel C, Lacey CJ, Soerjomataram I, Lortet-Tieulent J, Bruni L, Vignat J, Ferlay J, Bray F, Plummer M, Franceschi S. Global burden of human papillomavirus and related diseases. Vaccine. 2012 Nov 20;30 Suppl 5:F12-23. doi: 10.1016/j.vaccine.2012.07.055. PMID: 23199955.
about.agesInitEndScreening_Justification: International guidelines recommend that in the general population of women, starting regular cervical cancer screening at the age of 30 years among, with priority given to screening women aged 30–49 years. When tools are available to manage women aged 50–65 years, those in that age bracket who have never been screened should also be prioritized. Finally, stopping screening is recommended after the age of 50 years after two consecutive negative screening results consistent with the recommended regular screening intervals.
about.agesInitEndScreening_Source1: WHO guideline for screening and treatment of cervical pre-cancer lesions for cervical cancer prevention. Second edition. © World Health Organization 2021. ISBN: 978-92-4-003082-4.
